{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3142648,"name":"Brian","username":"JasonxDbD202","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/57b2e6/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-02-09T19:31:29.689Z","cooked":"

I’m trying to figure out how to program a pneumatics system where it can start automatically and there is a two button system where one button releases pressure into one side and the same goes for the other button, and how can I make it where if the pressure slowly goes down to like 120 psi I can program it to let psi in or if there’s too much psi it stops adding psi, or does it do that by default?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2023-02-09T19:31:29.689Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":20,"reads":215,"readers_count":214,"score":148.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":426268,"topic_slug":"pneumatics","display_username":"Brian","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":56815,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/pneumatics/426268/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true,"can_vote":false},{"id":3142677,"name":"Chris Gerth","username":"gerthworm","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gerthworm/{size}/268658_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-09T19:59:33.334Z","cooked":"

Lots of questions in one here. I’m not sure I’m fully parsing the questions out correctly, but I’ll take a shot at it.

JasonxDbD202:

there is a two button system where one button releases pressure into one side

Sounds like the example code here might be similar. Yes, there are methods you can call in code to change a solenoid’s electrical state, which directs air to different parts of your system.

JasonxDbD202:

how can I make it where if the pressure slowly goes down to like 120 psi I can program it to let psi in or if there’s too much psi it stops adding psi,

These docs might be of interest as well. The pneumatics control electronics automatically regulate operation to maintain storage pressure at near 120PSI. You have the option to disable the compressor altogether if desired.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2023-02-09T19:59:33.334Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":199,"readers_count":198,"score":39.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":426268,"topic_slug":"pneumatics","display_username":"Chris Gerth","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://docs.wpilib.org/en/stable/docs/software/hardware-apis/pneumatics/pneumatics.html#generating-and-storing-pressure","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Operating pneumatic cylinders — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation","clicks":4},{"url":"https://docs.wpilib.org/en/stable/docs/software/hardware-apis/pneumatics/pneumatics.html#single-solenoids-in-wpilib","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Operating pneumatic cylinders — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation","clicks":2}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24617,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/pneumatics/426268/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3142719,"name":"Al Skierkiewicz Learn Something New, Every Day!","username":"Al_Skierkiewicz","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/al_skierkiewicz/{size}/110877_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-09T21:03:24.839Z","cooked":"

Robot rules require storage pressure to be at 120 psi or below. If using a standard pressure switch, the compressor will turn on when the robot is enabled if the pressure is below 120 psi (~110 psi) and then turn it off when it approaches 120 psi. If using the analog Rev sensor, then you can program where the compressor turns on but it still may not exceed 120 psi. If you are frequently running out of working pressure (60psi) then you might want to consider adding another storage tank.

Ok I was able to program it no errors in the terminal but when I built it and deployed it, the driver station terminal was saying “ERROR 1: edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.PneumaticsHub$DataStorage!
And edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.RobotBase.runRobotBase.Java:312

I think you’re going to have to show us a little more of that message. It seems very strange. The Java class PneumaticsHub was renamed to PneumaticHub in 2021. Can you get a screenshot?

It may be of benefit to you to download the document in the link below and study it to get a better understanding of how the pneumatic system works. Having the system built correctly will allow the software to work properly.

You may also want to reach out to other more established teams in your area and ask them to look over your robot. They may notice things that are connected incorrectly and will cause you grief and/or things that are not allowed in the rules and will prevent your robot from passing inspection.

https://www.google.com/url?q=https://firstfrc.blob.core.windows.net/frc2017/pneumatics-manual.pdf&sa=U&ved=2ahUKEwi9jeLuwYn9AhVtk2oFHYqLC30QFnoECAsQAg&usg=AOvVaw1HkxeoaFIHm3JBzQQURfBf

JasonxDbD202:

can I also get data from the pneumatics like the psi?

If you’re using an analog sensor, then you should be able to call PneumaticHub.getPressure(0). You might also like getCompressorCurrent().

what if I’m not using an analog sensor, could i still return a psi current?

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2023-02-11T04:37:43.250Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":41,"readers_count":40,"score":13.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":426268,"topic_slug":"pneumatics","display_username":"Brian","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":38743,"username":"bovlb","name":"Gavin Matthews","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bovlb/{size}/167232_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":56815,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/pneumatics/426268/11","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3143583,"name":"Fletch","username":"Fletch1373","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/fletch1373/{size}/220073_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-11T04:52:34.013Z","cooked":"

No. A digital pressure switch only has 2 possible states, open and closed. The switch will open when at/above its configured pressure (~120psi), and will close when below ~90psi (I believe). The compressor cannot be commanded to run when the switch is open (including if the sensor wire is accidentally disconnected, as a safety feature). You may be able to return the state of that switch, but all it would tell you is which side of that threshold pressure you’re currently at.

An analog pressure sensor will return a variable voltage depending on the current pressure in the system. The PH can read this voltage and interpret it as a pressure. This is why you’re able to get this value with analog but not with digital.
